In case you missed it, here is my contribution</a> for mixtape madness this year, in a downloadable format. And here is the rather lengthy notes I wrote down to accompany them, because I am sad and have to talk</i> about music as well as give it.

ANOTHER </span>MIXTAPE BY MATT WITH PRETENTIOUS ‘ROUGH TRADE’ STYLE COMMENTS, THIS ONE IS KIND OF ABOUT SOME SONGS HE HAS BEEN LISTENING TO LATELY, SO ENJOY I GUESS</o:p></b></p>

</span>1. </span></span></span></b>Circles – Jellybones (2008, Crunchy Records)</o:p></b></p>

Improves upon an already great song by the Unicorns, by ramping up the tempo and pouring 8-bit electro all over it. Definitely my favourite cover of recent months.</p>

</span>2. </span></span></span></b>Crystal Stilts – The SinKing (2009, Slumberland Records)</o:p></b></p>

So, imagine that Joy Division decided to form a shoegaze group. It sounds a bit like that. Lots of reverb, humming bassline, a bleak baritone voice, and a dreamy, dark sound. Part of the newly emergent Brooklyn scene, along with..</p>

</span>3. </span></span></span></b>The Pains of Being Pure at Heart – Everything With You (2009, Fortuna Pop)</o:p></b></p>

So, Fortuna Pop finally got a breakthrough band. I’ve met Sean, who runs their label, and he’s a lovely guy who’s lost a lot of money, and also happens to ALSO have a full time job. Props to that. POBPAH sound almost exactly like Ecstasy & Wine </i>by My Bloody Valentine: hazy, beautiful, awash with guitars and dripping with the delicious sound of pop music. My favourite record of the year.</p>

</span>4. </span></span></span></b>Pocketbooks – Cross the Line (2009, How Does it Feel to be Loved?)</o:p></b></p>

Oh hello, Pocketbooks! The greatest indiepop band around that has nothing distinguishable about them. This song is currently my favourite off their debut album Flight Paths</i>, I think it is about two old friends bumping into one another in London and telling each other about their lives. As someone who lives in London, I find this song actually quite funny.</p>

</span>5. </span></span></span></b>Wake the President – Miss Tierney (2009, Electric Honey)</o:p></b></p>

Glasgow is the home of indiepop, and has turned out this rather lovely group recently. When I saw them live, they looked like Amish, with their top buttons done up on their flannel shirts, their huge acoustic guitars, the fact it was in a fucking wooden church</i>. Twangy, poppy, and literate, it’s not a million miles from The Smiths.</p>

</span>6. </span></span></span></b>The Attery Squash – Charlie Brooker is Right About Everything (2009, unsigned)</o:p></b></p>

This is a slight change of the actual single “Devo was right about everything”, but this one has become more famous. It’s probably because Charlie Brooker is actually right about everything ever.</i> </p>

</span>7. </span></span></span></b>Disasteradio – Awesome Feelings (2009, A Low Hum)</o:p></b></p>

Existing somewhere in a distant land, there’s a fucking mental overweight New Zealander who likes to dance and make bloopy 80s sounds. His name is Luke, and he has a project called Disasteradio. He describes himself as the Asda version of Kraftwerk.</p>

</span>8. </span></span></span></b>Fucked Up – Days of Last (2008, Matador)</o:p></b></p>

I’m not usually a fan of hardcore, but The Chemistry of Common Living</i> is an ace record, and thoroughly deserves its acclaim. Amazing lyrics, amazing guitars, and music that for once doesn’t just sound like it’s trying to be cool.</p>

</span>9. </span></span></span></b>Butcher Boy – Carve a Pattern (2009, How Does it Feel to be Loved?)</o:p></b></p>

Elder labelmates of Pocketbooks, these (eight?) young lads have managed to go unnoticed by myself until Indietracks, and then I promptly ignored </span>them for another few months. I shouldn’t have. Soulful, tender, and unique.</p>

</o:p></p>

</o:p></p>

</span>10. </span></span></span></b>The Absentee – Something to Bang (2006, Memphis Records)</o:p></b></p>

Coming from the same label as the Pipettes and Lucky Soul, I suppose you’d expect a girl fronted 60s band. Not really. Gruff, swaggering vocals set the scene for something that sounds a bit more like a pop version of Mark Lanegan.</p>

</o:p></p>

</span>11. </span></span></span></b>The Felt Tips – Not Tonight (2007, Wee Pop)</o:p></b></p>

Also from Glasgow. These guys had the privilege of supporting the LUCKSMITHS (!) on their farewell tour. Crooning vocals and shimmering guitars sound straight out of 80s indie. This song has some of my favourite lyrics of all time, some funny and tragically true facts about trying to lose your virginity.</p>

</span>12. </span></span></span></b>The Pearly Gatecrashers – Mobile Shack (Elefant, 1995)</o:p></b></p>

The Pearly Gatecrashers are a twee band from the 90s, but I’m mainly interested in this because it’s an exceptionally good Felt cover. Felt were the project of Lawrence Hayward, and they created 10 albums and 10 singles in 10 years. Their keyboardist was Martin Duffy, who went to Primal Scream. They were contemporaries of (but unfortunately overshadowed by) The Smiths, and really fucking great.</i></p>

</span>13. </span></span></span></b>Help Stamp Out Loneliness – Record Shop (2009, WIAIWYA / Papillions Noir)</o:p></b></p>

So I was hanging around the Hangar stage of Indietracks, and killing time between bands. I really can’t remember who I was waiting for, but I had seen the lead singer between bands and I was PERSONALLY OFFENDED by her outfit (tacky looking sparkly gold dress). I was made to eat my hat on this one, they were stunning. Mainly due to her deep, beautiful voice. If you YouTube these guys I have like the 3rd</sup> video. Rock on.</p>

</span>14. </span></span></span></b>Voletron </span>– I Remember U (2009, unsigned)</o:p></b></p>

Inner geek showing, if it hasn’t already. Guy decides to sample </span>badly acted Warcraft boss vocals with a famously mental raid leader, backed by some Ed Banger style electro. I hate to admit it, but BRILLIANCE, PURE BRILLIANCE.</p>

</span>15. </span></span></span></b>Teenage Fanclub – I Don’t Want Control of You (1997, Creation)</o:p></b></p>

The pioneers of power pop themselves (and ALSO FROM GLASGOW), the more I listen to them, the greater they become. This one’s on Songs from Northern Britain</i>, but I must say Grand Prix</i> is their best and most consistent record. I don’t know how they do it, but the music aches with emotion I’ve scarcely heard in any other band.</p>

</span>16. </span></span></span></b> </span>Malcolm Middleton </span>- A Brighter Beat (2007, Chemikal Underground)</o:p></b></p>

One half of Arab Strap continues, with a slightly more upbeat take on music. But not on life, judging by the other single from this album, We’re All Going to Die,</i> which had him dressed as a drunk Father Christmas on Oxford Street proclaiming the end of the world. The video to this song is well worth checking out.</p>

</span>17. </span></span></span></b>Fighter X – Hypergiant (2008, Crunchy Records)</o:p></b></p>

If you haven’t noticed by now, I love</b> Crunchy Records. They are one of the largest chiptune labels in the world, which is the bizarre genre of composing your music entirely from old 8bit videogames. Fighter X are one of the label’s highlights, along with industry heavyweights Sabrepulse.</p>

</span>18. </span></span></span></b>Northern Portrait – In an Empty Hotel (2009, Matinée Recordings)</o:p></b></p>

I put a lot of random shit on my mp3 player, and I had the rare pleasure of randomly discovering these guys whilst walking around Hammersmith station. I played it again and again. And again. Highly vulnerable and crooning Morrissey-esque vocals lead this sweeping and emotional track. They are, oddly enough, from Denmark.</p>

</span>19. </span></span></span></b>Trembling Blue Stars – November Starlings (2007, Elefant)</o:p></b></p>

This song has a really nostalgic tint to it, almost like it’s in slow motion. Trembling Blue Stars are the latest project of Robert Wratten, lead singer of The Field Mice, the most famous band on the influential record label Sarah.</p>

</span>20. </span></span></span></b>Del Amitri – Hammering Heart (1985, Chrysalis Records)</o:p></b></p>

This is my ‘thing’ for John Peel day, a brilliant little song I found from his Festive Fifties. Their record label got bought out by EMI in the 90s and used solely to release material for Robbie Williams. Pretty funny, huh?</p></div>
